Bottle at home. Pours deep brown, nose is funky, vinegar, wood, taste is balsamic, tart, zesty, light sweetness.

750ml bottle at Bar Gernika. Perfect cap to the evening. The blend works perfectly to bring a multitude of aromas and flavors into the mix. Heady fruity aroma, wine like overtones, velvety smooth. Sip and enjoy!
Now this is everything a sour ought to be. Dark reddish brown colour. Aroma is a bit of red wine and a bit of funk. Taste has some vinegar notes and a slightly tannic finish. Glorious.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2016 
Aroma:

Heavy aroma of malts, caramel, wood, grapes, berries, wine and acidity.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque red/brown beer with a medium beige/brown head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts, caramel, wood, grapes and berries; ends medium dry and sour with wine and acidity.

Overall:

This beer is intense, complex and balanced. The red ale with added grapes and aged in oak, the red ale aged in port and the red ale aged in pinot noir are perfect together. The wine flavour these three ales create is simply superb and unbeatable.

Wonderful beer, really great. The perfect sourness, never artificial. The other flavors of the barrels get through after a while as well. Perfection.

Draft at Oedipus International Beer Festival. Clear amber brown with a tan head. Aroma of tart red fruit, malt, caramel, overripe dark fruits and toffee. Flavour is moderate sweet and sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

On tap at OIBF¬í16. Hazy dark brown colour, off-white head. Lovely aroma of oak, vanilla, red wine, light funk, acid, balsamic vinegar, wood. From tap at Oedipus International Beer Festival 2016. Aroma is huge oak, malt, tart red fruits, balsamic vinegar, caramel, wine, sour grapes. Flavour is nicely strong sour and tart with a hint of sweetness. Body is medium. Huge beer yet quite drinkable, like an oak aged Flanders Red/Brown on steroids. Very good!

Draft at Oedipus fest. Aroma of red fruit, tart and oak. Rich taste of red vinous fruit, oak, mild tart and ripe fruit. Very good.

On tap @ Oedipus Int. Beer Festival 2016. Nose is fruity sourish wild yeasty, cherry. Body is clear deep ruby brown, head is very small, beige, mostly diminishing, fair lacing. Aroma is sour apple, cherry, bubble gum, red wine. Medium sweet, heavy sour. Finish is medium lasting wineish medium sour. Full body, dry texture, nearly flat carbonation. Flavor is fairly acidic, but with a moderate sweetness to balance the acidity. Malt notes with toasted bread, caramel and toffee. Quite a bit of dark fruit with raisin, plum, prune, fig, berries and most of all, cherries. Moderate red wine notes with lighter oak and tannins. Some light alcohol spice. Lingering vinegar, alcohol, dark fruit and red wine. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a decent sour beer but it¬ís a bit big for my preferences. Lots of dark fruit and red wine notes. A touch of vinegar and too much alcohol.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2014 Bottle 75l @2nd TSRG. An amber red beer with low head. Nose is very acid like with cherry touch. Aroma is on red dry fruits, cloves, vinegar, vinous and very very acid, even bile notes, some complexity but really my cup of tea.

On draught at Cascade Barrel House. 2012 project at 10.12% ABV. Full amber color. Aroma is red wine, dark cherry, and some light tart funkiness. Taste is earthy, with light tartness and pinot noir, sour cherry, and leather notes. Very dry finish, with sour cherry and that earthy note in the aftertaste.

2012 On draught at cascade / pours cloudy amber with small head. Nose of drinking vinegar, malt, fruit. Taste is of tart plum, caramel, malt, and definite Cabernet Sauvignon notes.

Bottle during RBSG 2014. Dark amber brown with off-white head. Aromas of vinegar, funk, cheese. Tastes of vinegar, dark fruit, tart notes, oak. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Another nice sour from Cascade.

Bottle @ Presidential Suite. Thanks, Sean. Garnet/ruby pour with a tall khaki head. Super acidic aroma. Lots of dark fruit such as currants and black cherry. Slight solvent, fair amount of vinegar, green apple, and lemons. Flavor is intensely sour. Tons of red wine vinegar and lemon juice. Slightly vinous. Lots of currant and black cherry. Big time green apple, too.
Bottle shared at RBSG. Pours a reddish brown color with white head. Cherry, oak, fruity aromas. Cherry juice, jam, juicy juice flavors.

Bottle: Thanks, Ed. 2009 Project. Mahogany, muddled body with a red/copper tint to it; khaki head fades instantly to a ring. Aroma of sharp cherry skins, some vinous grapes, a hint of booze & plenty of sourness. Oak, vine, & mild notes of port mix with a borderline acidic tartness in the back-end. Taste is crazy sour, think Black Cherry Warhead. Off the charts pucker with subtle red grape sweetness to pull the tide back. Vinous wood, light booze, & some fading lemon & yogurty lacto notes leading to a sharp, dry, post-puckering finish. A little bit of spicy oak left on the palate. Yet another deliciously sour beer from Cascade... This one is upper echelon.

Had this toward the end of a long day at RBSG, so my notes are messy and my palate was likely wrecked. Orange with ginger and a hint of nail polish. Very acetic and chest burning. Very harsh without much balance.

This is one of numerous sours made by numerous breweries that seems to have some sort of endlessly complicated aging and blending process that leads to something that is not ultimately very special tasting in the long run. It is brown red in color with a little ring of head. It has a quality that I just generally dislike which is that it is both very sour and rather sweet which combined w/ woody notes from the barrel aging process always reminds me quite a lot of drinking barbecue sauce. I really just can¬ít get into this one.

Taster from a bottle at RBSG hotel room. Hazy dark red color. Thin off-white ring of head. Smooth, kind of soft crisp, lighter carbonation. Light slick finish. Bigger sour taste. Light sweet, light spicy wood tannin. Dark fruit, cherry. Light wine character. Nice stuff.
2009 bottle. Dark ruby red pour, sour aroma, oak, tart cherries, and leather. Taste, sour ketchup, leather, funk, dry finish. Solid sour.

Courtesy of OHLRangers
Bottle (2009): The aroma consists of cherries, lemon, faint apple, and faint cola. It pours a dark orangish-brown with some transparency when held to the light. It has a minimal beige head that quickly fades to a few stray bubbles. The flavor starts with a quick dose of cherries with a hint of cola. The finish has moderate-heavy sour lemon and sweet tarts. Overall, super sour without any acetone, so I¬ím loving this.

Pours maroon. Smell is cherry tart fruit some balanced sweetness smooth. Taste is sour cherry very light vinegar, cranberries. Like visne juice carbonated and a bit more acidic. Very nice.crisp very tasty!

Bottle with thanks to CallMeMickey. Pours a murky purplish hazel with a small kinda fizzy tan head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving a ring that laces pretty well. Aroma is very vinous, oaky, tart cherries, red wine. Flavor is quite tart, mouth puckering and during. Tons of oak and vinous qualities here - Pinot is really coming through, grapey, just a touch of musty funk going on. Finish is lingering tart, lemony, vinous. There might be some oaky astringency, but it is honestly hard to tell with all the sourness. This is good, but you had better like sour before you crack this baby

2009 bottle purchased at Raccoon Lodge & Brew Pub, Portland, OR (9.345% ABV according to the bottle). Muddy reddish-brown pour with a thin frothy off-white head. Aroma of tart cherries, red wine, and apple cider vinegar. Beautiful sour taste of lemon, pinot noir, and dark fruit rounded with oak and hints of dark chocolate. The sour lingers on the palate long after the initial taste. Even at 5 years this is a stunning beer. (Replaces an earlier review from GABF 2009).
Poured a darker amber color with aromas of vinous grapes, light wine, some wet wood, and funk. Flavors were a mixture of the aromas, not overly powering wine notes, decent funk and sourness.

2009 project. Original bottling, I presume? Pours a seep red amber with a small head that faded quickly. Aromas of tart red grapes, oak, funk. Flavors of very sour grapes, mossy oak, deep black cherry, white pepper. Dirty and funky but very mature. Well developed. Deep port-like character. Subdued carbonation yet still lively on the tongue. Finishes very dry and mouth puckering. Tasted this side by side with a 2013 consecration and this beer wins, but only barely.

Sample from 2009 bottle at Kurtkeller 006: Cascade-tastic 01 on 02/21/2014. Pours a cloudy dark reddish-amber color with a medium off-white head that dissipates steadily to a film. Oaky aroma with notes of red wine and cherries. Medium-bodied with a vinous character and notes of red cherries, vanilla and oak. The finish is moderately tart with a cherry wine aftertaste. Good all around.

pours a hazy dark brown with no head, aroma of vinegar, sour cherries, oak and red wine. taste is sour, cherries, redwine, oak and alcohol. very sour, almost hard to drink, gets better as it warms. a lot more complex as it warms. not bad

Bottle. What better way to celebrate a fun winter mountain bike ride with a Cascade sour. Pours a nice reddish brown color with a light tan head. Complex; fruity, tart, and a touch bit earthy, all culiminate to be pretty well balanced. Not overly sour but sour enough. Really enjoyed this one.
Bottle. Pours reddish brown with brown head. Nose and taste of cherry vinegar, wine barrel, grapes, oak, port, cocoa, caramel and sour funk. Medium body. Acidic.

Bottle. Pours out a nice reddish hued brown color with a moderate off white head. Aroma is of sweet/sour cherries, oak, funk, dried fruits and light vinegar. Taste is complex, tart/lightly sweet cherries, oak, vinegar, light funky basement must, rich leathery earthy notes, some lingering funky/tart/acidic notes that hang around with some sweetness that creeps in also. What a sour should taste like.

This one poured a semi murky Ruby red color with a beige head. Aroma was of red wine, dark fruits, caramel, and brown sugar. Flavor was a great blend of grape tannins and mild funk, followed but deep cherry and plum notes. Definitely my favorite cascade sour.
Not too much notes on this one... Medium bodied, vinous. Nice winey/grapey nose. Sour (lactic) with not much acetic acid to be felt (a good thing). A really good Cascade sour.

cascade + upright tasting sessions - thanks to all. pours murky brown with a nice beige head, some retention and lacing. phenolic grapes, spicy, boozy, acetic, red grape skin, hint of sweetness - some concord grape juice along with cherries. tad sweet and boozy. medium body, moderate carbonation. nice but not outstanding.

750 ml bottle shared with Tom and chums. Pours an opaque reddish brown with a thin, nice beige head. Aroma is oak, cherries, grapes, vanilla. Flavor is very, very fruity. Especially cherry. Go figure? Hints of chocolate, other red berries. Finish is caramel, wood, tartness, sour grapes. A bit like a good red wine, basically. Medium body, average carbonation. Very flavorful, very good.

Bottle (750 ml). Project 2009. From jp7161, thanks! Slightly hazy amber with a small beige head and little lacing. Aroma is of oak, red fruits, Port, wine, tobacco, acetic notes and light ketchup. Taste is slightly to moderately sweet with vanilla, oak, red fruits, acetic, wine and light ketchup. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Winey mouthfeeel. Quite complex and not too acetic. Way better than Sang Noir. Good!

Bottle 750ml.
Pours hazy, murky brown/red with low beige head. Aroma is of cherries, tobacco. Taste is of cherries, fruits. Palate: Medium body. Overall: Sweet, fruity. Not too acetic unlike other Cascade.

Bottle from Tom10101, thanks a lot! Pour is hazy brown with beige head. Aroma of grapes, oak, acidic, caramel, dark fruits. Taste is grapes, oak, acetic notes, dark fruits. Low-med body and med carb. Pretty good!

Ruddy brown color with a beige head. Grapes and wood primarily on the nose, overripe grapes and acidic berries. Flavor is lactic and acetic with cherry, grape, sour malt, red wine vinegar, wood, and a short acidic finish.

Bottle at share, Pours cloudy ruby with medium with tiny tan head. Aroma is tart cherry, wood, barrel funk, and cabernet. Flavor is a lot of the same with dates and vino dominating the palate. Long lasting finish with tart and complex sour notes. Smooth body with light to medium carbonation. Really enjoyed this one.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty sour tart woody aroma with hints of wine. Fruity sour tart woody red wine flavor. Has a very sour tart woody wine finish.

N: Red and green grape. Lactic acid as expected. Currants and plums. Fair amount of acetone and glue. More sharp lactic acid and some leather from the pinot barrels.

T: Tons of sharp lactic acid. Leather and currants. Sweet tarts, lemon,and sour clementine. Plums and vinous grapes. Some tannins.

M: Oily and slick, as is the Cascade norm. Alcohol is light.

O: Don¬ít know how much this has benefited from extended aging in the barrel. Puckeringly sour and lacking dimension. Meh. It doesn¬ít taste bad, but it no beauty, either.

Nose is big with the various booze barrels and funky lacto notes and they clash a little bit.  Also lots of tannins.   Flavor is big and and a bit messy at times, as evidenced by the nose.  An interesting/cool idea but in the end I think there are just too many different components to come together for this beer to harmonize like some other barrel aged sours.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy reddish amber brown color with a small off white head.  The aroma is tart/sour fruits, cherries, vinous, vinegar, wood and acidic. The aroma offers barnyard funk, oak, and sour cherries, vinegar, booze. Complex and intriguing...

Bold flavor and highly enjoyable. A lot of cherry flavor really shines through. Misc. dark fruits, oak, wine, wild yeast. Yeah baby. Acetic without being harsh. Again, complexities abound. A delightful sipper. One of the better brews by Cascade.

Serving type: bottle

¬í09 bottle drank 12/7/12.  Dark cloudy wine color.  Huge red wine and oak nose as well as brett and some volatile acid.  One of the more sour beers of the night in a sours tasting.  Grape tannin, tart dark forest fruits.  Just excellent, tart acetic balanced finish.

750ml bottle .. . always enjoy Cascade beers, and this one¬ís the same .. . ruby red .. mild foam, good lacing .. . tart and slick, deep cherry skin and barrel .. . really enjoyable

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours dark brown/black with beige head. Aroma is very berry acidic with very subtle hints of aged oak. Pours a slightly hazy brown pour with a tan head.  Aroma of grapes, almost seems a bit like Concord grapes rather than wine grapes.  A touch of chocolate and raisins. pour is dark murky brown with creamy light brown head. Nose is sour, light red grape and malt olive. More bright dark berry behind. Deep amber/brown.  Minimal, tan head.  Aroma indicates a sharp sourness that has elements of lactic, acetic, and unknown complex components.  Body is light and dry with fruitiness. sweet grape candy aroma. The body is quite heavy & thick, mouth-coating. A lot more grape in this than I was expecting-it works. The underlying sweetness and heavy feel balances well with the acidity. I can¬ít get over how this coats my teeth.

750 ml bottle shared by Jason- thanks again! 2009 Project. Pours a cloudy, deep amber color with no head. Aroma of tart berries, lemon, vanilla, caramel, and acetic acid. Bottle @ Fan√∏ Slumber Party, 2012. Pours cloudy amber with a small head. Wood, vanill and fruit. Acidic flavor with raspberries and prune. Smooth, dry and crisp. Nice.

750 ml. corked n¬í caged bottle, does 2009 project mean 2009 vintage?- Pours dark dark ruby red with big ugly bubbles that disappear immediately leaving a completely flat beer. Bottle at Fan√∏ Slumber Party. Thanks to Baron. Cloudy brown ¬ñ offwhite head. Nice rubber sourish, medium to high grapes, nice roasted, peppery. nice wooden, coconut notes, light caramel, lovely light acid, This is lovely.

Bottle @ Fan√∏ Slumber Party 2012.
Pours hazy deep chestnut with a small, creamy, beige film head. Aroma is sweet at first, cherries, caramel, plums, oak and a bit of chocolate. Medium to high carbonation, lovley fat and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is elegant, oak, red currants, plums, tartness, raspberries, red wine, blue grapes, apple zest and just a soft touch of vinegar. At brewpub. 10oz pour. Good aroma, tart , fruity. On the red berry side. Raspberry, strawberries. Nice funk about it. Brownish red color. Ok head and lace. Tart flavor. text: Cloudy chestnut colour with a small off-white head. Aroma of cherry, wood, malt and balsamic vinegar. Sweet and tart cherry flavour, red wine and balsamic vinegar with some nice oak.

Dark red brownish pour, light tan head.  Berry, acidic, grape, oak, vinous.  Q nice complex strong sour, but not something I would or could drink regularly.

Bottle. Pours murky burgundy with minimal beige head. Aroma has pleasant oakiness to it with red wine and sour cherries. Flavor is moderately acetic with some oak and cherry sweetness to complement the vinegar. Port wine and some dryness in the finish. Very nice!

Pour out of bottle at Avery Sourfest 2012, hazy orange pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of sour lemon, biscuit and caramel, touch of yeast, spice notes mix into a berry and slightly funky nose towards the end. 75cl, Vintage 2009, at 9.345%Vol, exclusive American brew, with red wine grapes, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex sour brew, sour/vinous and slightly woody/bitter, balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Wow - pours red amber thick ith a nice dark sandy red head. The aroma brings soured malt notes, quite nice and tangy with light alcohol cooling notes. The flavor is quite tart and sour but pleasant with notes of the red wine shining through potently and a tangy ending. So good.

@ Avery Sourfest 2012.  Opaque reddish brownish, with a small foamy beige head. Fruity sour aroma with some cherry and fig, with some wood and bretty like tone. One of my favourite sours up to now, just reading the description on the bottle you realise how much love has gone into this beer. Fruity wine taste and then a huge sour burst, lingers on your tongue long after you¬íve put the glass down. I¬ím just glad I got a few bottles of this great beer!!

750ml bottle, shared by the Enforcer. Pours a murky reddish-brown. Minimal head is tan to off-white, and rapidly diminishes. Aroma is funky, and oaky with lots of cherry and background grape. Bottle.  Nice clean sour dark chocolate covered cherries kissed by a pleasant cleant port and oak note.   Dry.   Tasty nice.

Flavors are puckering acid, grapes, maybe stewed tomatoes. The tartness take over completely. This one grabs the throat with acidity, creating an almost instant heartburn sensation. A truly extreme wild/sour beer. Great.

Big thanks to Maekchu for bringing this one back from the brewery. Filthy reddish brown color. Looks horrible, really. Big grape, wine, vinegar, cinnamon nose, with crazy fruit. Bottle shared by Blake, thanks!  Pour is deep cloudy brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is tart with hints of cherry, faint brown sugar, notes of wood, a touch of squash, and acetic acid. Flavor is super tart with hints of cherry, acetic acid, light wood, and sour heads. This is wicked tart and I love it. Great beer. Very drinkable and clean.

Bottle from 09. Pours murky red with a light tan ring for a head. Aroma is tart, sour cherries and oak. Flavor is tart, lots of cherry, oak. Nice tart finish. Medium carbonation and light bodied. Pretty good sour.

Had the 2010 blended with Bing and Sour Pie cherries . What a great tart, sour, acidic beer. Reddish brown in color with a light off white head. This is a beer you need to try, lots of cherries and funk, my pallet is not refined enough to pick out what is going on, but it sure is tasty.

Bottle brought to BenC¬ís huge BCS tasting by beerwolf77...thanks Todd!  Beers like this are why sours are dominating my ratings.  All I can say is that everything about this beer was great.  Thanks again Todd!

Bottle brought to BenC¬ís huge BCS tasting by beerwolf77...thanks Todd! - Pours murky brownish-read with a thin tan head. Nose is grape skins, red wine, a bit of malt, lemon rind, and Sweet Tarts. Such a complex beer with a huge amount of acidity and sourness which I loved. Just an easy drinking mouth-puckering "NW style sour" lol.

Bottle shared @ 5 Seasons North.  Pours a murky reddish brown with off white head.  The aroma is medium strong in the sour vinegar and cherry with nice oak notes. Yes!  Best sour Ive ever had.  Aroma is nicely fruity with grapes and cherries.  Taste is tart but not too vinegarous.  Flavor is heavy currants and berry with a nice oaky spicyness. GREAT
750 thanks to ben greenburg. Smells like supplication, the barrel aging is amazing, tastes tart and sour and a tiny bit funky.

Bottle, shared by my bro, thanks tim, had the 2009 project version, pretty tasty stuff, has a nice sour aroma, lots of bretty qualities, has a really sour taste and it is quite nice, the grapes add a lot to the finish in this one, really enjoyed thanks

Bottle at Paul¬ís Dec 3rd Tasting. Pours a murky brownish red body with light brown lacing. Aroma is sour cherry and wood. Mouthfeel is puckering tart and fruit. Another great sour of the night. Glad I was able to try this sucker.

750ml bottle courtesy of dcschiller. Pours deep red, almost brown in my snifter with a thin off-white head that fades to a thin ring. GABF ¬í09.  This is the best of the Cascade offerings that I was able to try.  Lovely deep red color with a medium, loose, light pink head. 750ml corked and caged bottle bomb.  This sucker was so pressurized, the cork blew the cage right off of the collar and I took a bath! The pour yields a deep, dark, garnet-mauve colored body, nice and cloudy, with a frothy, khaki colored head.  Tattered, broken cobweb lacing coats the glass well.  The aroma shows like an imperial Flemish red, with plenty of lactic tartness, semi-sweet cherry, vanilla laden oak, and a dark and fruity malt base. The flavor hits with a biting sourness up front, fermented cherry showing strong, transitioning into sweeter blackberry notes with loads of oak and worn leather, then diving right back into tart cherry and fine Balsamic vinegar on the finish.  It¬ís a pretty intense roller coaster ride, going from sour to sweet and then sour again.  The woody oak really concentrates on the finish, which lingers for a good while.  Lively carbonation pushes everything along swiftly, the palate showing initially full and sweet, but ending up on the drier side.  This is definitely the best Cascade sour I¬íve had to date.  Great beer......but fix the cage issue before someone loses an eye!

text: Pours ruby-tinged mahogany into a tumbler. Off-white micro head with excellent retention leaves spider lacing. Sour cherry aromas. Tart and refreshing with sour cherry and oak from front to back.  Lasting port finish.

This beer is quite the gusher; I actually lost a couple of ounces before I could react to the foam over.  A careful pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces an almost four-finger thick, amber tinged, tan colored head.  As the head slowly subsides with a rocky, crag-riddled surface it leaves some nice fat lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is a dark plum color that shows a hazy, rich red hue when it is held up to the light.  The aroma is quite vinous and smells of dark fruit; notes of prunes, raisins, lots of black currant, as well as some bright cherry and berry notes (this last reminds me of blackberries, blueberries and mulberries).  There is a backdrop of toasty oak in the nose as wellas a touch of toasted grain effect; some tannin, a spicy oak character and a hint of vanillin are noticeable.  The nose on this beer is pretty nice, it is well integrated and rich smelling, though I could wish for a touch more complexity.

The beer tastes lightly tart up front. It has a palate fullness and heft to it, which a lively, effervescent carbonation tries to offset; it is actually a bit excessively carbonated, but the body of the beer still stands up to this excess quite well.  A nice sourness can almost be bracing, it couples with a tannic bite towards the finish that makes this that much more puckering.  Spicy oak and wood flavors play a more prominent role than they did in the nose, but the fruitiness is much more subdued in the flavor; this last is likely because this beer is quite dry tasting, with little residual sugars.  Still the fruit notes are noticeable here and remind me of a dry, fruit forward red wine; notes of berry, dark-concentrated plum, tart currant flavors, some washed out cherry skin and even some port-like fruit notes are noticeable here.  As the beer warms up the fruit does become more evident though.  There is a tart bite from the acidity that is most lactic, but there also seemed to be a rounded acid influence from the fruit character.  Especially after the beer settles down (from the initial carbonation level), the texture is lush and structed from the tannic influence, yet it is still quite drinkable; velvet-like and silky seem like apt adjectives for this brew.  There is some spice character here as well and a bit of a biting note that is contributed by the rich fruit / malt character (sort of reminiscent of a spicy fruit skin flavor).

I like that this has a nice oak backbone to it; that and the tartness really helps to bring a suave balance to the jam-like, rich fruit character.  I paired this beer with some fish tacos for the last 25cl and this brings out a peppery spiciness from the oak as well as more of the wood-like flavors, but what it really does is accentuate the rich fruit character that is in this beer.  This is a really nice, rich, complex, layered beer that retains its ample drinkability.  A fantastic beer, that I am quite happy to have polished a bottle off of.
